review.title: The Learning and Prediction of Application-level Traffic Data in Cellular Networks
review.abstract: Traffic learning and prediction is at the heart of the evaluation of the performance of telecommunications networks and attracts a lot of attention in wired broadband networks. Now, benefiting from the big data in cellular networks, it becomes possible to make the analyses one step further into the application level. In this paper, we firstly collect a significant amount of application-level traffic data from cellular network operators. Afterwards, with the aid of the traffic "big data", we make a comprehensive study over the modeling and prediction framework of cellular network traffic. Our results solidly demonstrate that there universally exist some traffic statistical modeling characteristics, including ALPHA-stable modeled property in the temporal domain and the sparsity in the spatial domain. Meanwhile, the results also demonstrate the distinctions originated from the uniqueness of different service types of applications. Furthermore, we propose a new traffic prediction framework to encompass and explore these aforementioned characteristics and then develop a dictionary learning-based alternating direction method to solve it. Besides, we validate the prediction accuracy improvement and the robustness of the proposed framework through extensive simulation results.
histories: Accepted by IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications on March 26, 2017

metadata.title: The Learning and Prediction of Application-level Traffic Data in Cellular Networks

sections.text: In fact, it is a way of putting oneself at the centre of the public's attention, benefiting from the large data networks on mobile networks. Firstly, in this paper we collect a significant amount of application-relevant traffic data from mobile operators and operators.

sections.heading: A. Related Works
sections.text: Due to its obvious importance, two research streams already exist on the problem of fine traffic forecasting in wired broadband networks and mobile networks [7]. One is based on adaptation models (e.g. ON-OFF model [12], ARIMA model [13], FARIMA model [14], mobility model [15], [16], network traffic model [16] and alpha-stable model [17], [18]) in order to study traffic characteristics such as spatial and temporal relevance [19] or self-similarity [20], [21] and to obtain future traffic through appropriate prediction methods; the other is based on modern signal processing techniques (e.g. the method of main component analysis [22], the Kalman filter method [23], [24] or the compressive sensor method [2], [11], [22], [25]) in order to understand the evolution of traffic linear, some traffic selectivity is necessary in the intermediate space of large-scale traffic.

sections.heading: B. Contribution
sections.text: Compared to the previous work, this work, which is one of the pioneers of traffic analysis at the application level, is dependent on a large number of practical records (as summarized in Table I and Table II) from China Mobile and provides the following key findings: • First, this work draws on α-stable models and confirms their accuracy to model traffic at the application level for all three types of service (i.e., IM, web browsing, video). Furthermore, this work shows traffic at the application level and shows the different properties between the different types of service. Therefore, the work contributes to a general understanding of network traffic. • Second, to capture and explore these properties, this work provides a framework for traffic forecasting in Fig. 1. Specifically, the proposed framework consists of x x models for generating rough predictive results.

sections.heading: A. α-Stable Models

sections.heading: IV. APPLICATION-LEVEL TRAFFIC PREDICTION FRAMEWORK
sections.text: The proposed framework consists of three modules, including the "α-Stable Model & Prediction" module, which would use the already known traffic knowledge to learn and distill the parameters in α-stable models and provide a rough forecast result. Meanwhile, the "Sparsity & Dictionary Learning" module imposes constraints to ensure that the final prediction results satisfy the spatial scarcity, but these two modules inevitably add several parameters without known a priori and therefore require specific mathematical operations to obtain a solution. Therefore, the proposed framework also includes an "Alternating Direction Method" module to iteratively process the other modules and achieve the final result.

sections.heading: V. PERFORMANCE EVALUATION
sections.text: We validate the predictive accuracy of our proposed framework in Algorithm 2, which is based on the practical traffic data (1). Specifically, we select the traffic congestion data of these three types of service generated in 113 cells within a randomly selected region of Dataset 1. In addition, we purposely divide the traffic data set into two parts, one used to learn and evaluate the parameters related to the traffic characteristics, and the other part consists in conducting the experiments to verify and validate the accuracy of the proposed framework in Algorithm 2. Specifically, we compare our prediction x-p with the ground-based truth x in relation to the standardized mean absolute errors (NMAE) defined asNMAE = 1. (i). (i). (i). (i). (i). (i). (i). (i). (i).

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this thesis we collected the traffic data at the application level of an operator in China. With the help of these practical traffic data we confirmed some important statistical characteristics such as temporally α-stable modeled property and spatial sparseness. Then we proposed a traffic forecasting framework that uses the already known traffic knowledge to distill the parameters related to the above traffic characteristics and predict future traffic results with the same characteristics. Furthermore, we developed a lexicon learning-based method to solve the framework and demonstrated the effectiveness and robustness of our algorithm through extensive simulation results.

metadata.abstractText: Traffic learning and prediction is at the heart of the evaluation of the performance of telecommunications networks and attracts a lot of attention in wired broadband networks. Now, benefiting from the big data in cellular networks, it becomes possible to make the analyses one step further into the application level. In this paper, we firstly collect a significant amount of application-level traffic data from cellular network operators. Afterwards, with the aid of the traffic “big data”, we make a comprehensive study over the modeling and prediction framework of cellular network traffic. Our results solidly demonstrate that there universally exist some traffic statistical modeling characteristics, including α-stable modeled property in the temporal domain and the sparsity in the spatial domain. Meanwhile, the results also demonstrate the distinctions originated from the uniqueness of different service types of applications. Furthermore, we propose a new traffic prediction framework to encompass and explore these aforementioned characteristics and then develop a dictionary learning-based alternating direction method to solve it. Besides, we validate the prediction accuracy improvement and the robustness of the proposed framework through extensive simulation results.
